body:
> I'd like to add a `--dropbox-credentials` flag so that a user is able to supply an inline JSON blob in order to fully automate authentication to Dropbox. It would work just like Drive's `--drive-service-account-credentials` flag.

Are these credentials a service account JWT like google drive?  Or are they effectively the same as you can find in the `token` field in the rclone config?  If the latter then there might be a better way of solving the problem.

If the former - what would you think about making two flags (so it is consistent with drive/gcs)

      --dropbox-service-account-credentials string   Service Account Credentials JSON blob
      --dropbox-service-account-file string          Service Account Credentials JSON file path

Would storing the credentials in a file be easier for people?

issue.title: [WIP] All Backends: add --backend-token flag - fixes #2849

repository.name: rclone
repository.description: "rsync for cloud storage" - Google Drive, S3, Dropbox, Backblaze B2, One Drive, Swift, Hubic, Wasabi, Google Cloud Storage, Azure Blob, Azure Files, Yandex Files

issue.body:
_*Note:* The scope of this PR now includes adding a similar `token` flag to each backend in Rclone. (In addition to the original Dropbox request.)_

#### What is the purpose of this change?

Add a `--dropbox-token` flag so that a user is able to supply an Access Token (as a JSON blob) outside of the default `rclone.conf` file. Use of this option (in conjunction with --dropbox-client-id
and --dropbox-client-secret) would allow users to to keep all plaintext credentials off-disk.

#### Was the change discussed in an issue or in the forum before?

No, just in the Github issue section. Please see #2849.

#### Checklist

- [x] I have read the [contribution guidelines](https://github.com/ncw/rclone/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#submitting-a-pull-request).
- [ ] I have added tests for all changes in this PR if appropriate.
- [x] I have added documentation for the changes if appropriate.
- [x] All commit messages are in [house style](https://github.com/ncw/rclone/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#commit-messages).
- [ ] I'm done, this Pull Request is ready for review :-)

body: Hello @ncw! I am interested in this feature (especially being able to pass in the oauth token json blob for all oauth backends as discussed in #2852). I can take a crack at implementing. Do you know if there has been any other discussion of this feature elsewhere in the backlog?

@ncw I can confirm that just adding a `config.ConfigToken` option to the options list works as expected. `oauthutil` can handle everything from there. It should be quick work to sprinkle that option in where needed.

```
$ ./rclone --dropbox-token '{"access_token":"foo","token_type":"bearer","expiry":"0001-01-01T00:00:00Z"}' lsl :dropbox:
   320669 2020-01-23 20:00:13.000000000 test1.txt
   357605 2020-01-23 20:00:25.000000000 test2.txt
   320669 2020-01-23 20:00:13.000000000 test3.txt
   357605 2020-01-23 20:00:25.000000000 test4.txt
```

In terms of factoring these options out do you have anything particular in mind? Would we want these options to still be exposed as `--$BACKEND-client-id`, etc.? We could add global flags like `--oauth-token`. That would work for my particular use case since I'm interested in generating configs on the fly with the `:backend:` syntax (syncing to/from the local fs). This might not provide as much flexibility to users who are performing actions between two oauth backends. Best of both worlds might be to maintain these backend specific options but add support for global flags like `--oauth-token`, `--oauth-client-id`, `--oauth-client-secret`. What are your thoughts?

> thinking about this some more... how about this as an option for factoring:

That looks great! `token` should be an advanced setting too.

To retain the current order in `rclone config` we'll need to put the oauth config options first
